review_title: Pros and cons of working at Starbucks
pros: Flexible scheduling: Starbucks is known for offering flexible scheduling options to its employees, which can be especially beneficial for students or those with other commitments. Employee benefits: Starbucks offers a range of benefits to its employees, including health insurance, 401(k) matching, and stock options. Opportunities for growth: Starbucks is a large and well-established company, and as such, it provides many opportunities for employees to grow and advance within the company. Work-life balance: Starbucks places a strong emphasis on work-life balance, and many employees report that the company culture fosters a positive and supportive work environment. Employee training: Starbucks provides comprehensive training programs for its employees, including ongoing training and development opportunities to help employees grow and improve their skills.
cons: Fast-paced environment: Starbucks locations can be high-volume and fast-paced, which can be challenging for some employees, especially during peak hours. Long hours: Depending on the location and role, employees at Starbucks may be required to work early mornings, evenings, weekends, and holidays. Physical demands: Some aspects of the job, such as making coffee drinks and cleaning, can be physically demanding and require employees to stand for long periods of time. Customer service: As with any retail or food service job, employees at Starbucks are expected to provide excellent customer service, which can be stressful and challenging at times. Competition for promotions: As Starbucks is a large company with many employees, there can be significant competition for promotions and advancement opportunities

They didn’t treat me well, often calling me “slow” when they were often distracted with his phone while on the job. pros:
Fun and engaging place to work in.

Gain first-hand experience in making different types of coffee and other drinks.

Mostly supportive managers and partners who do their best to guide you.

Challenging moments like serving peak hour crowds that train your ability to think on your feet.

Communicate with different kinds of customers.
cons:
Low pay and slow increment. You often end up spending much more than you save and need to pass an advanced coffee knowledge course to have a slight pay raise.

Learning-on-the-job system, being forced to learn their tens of different drink recipes by making them for actual customers, despite having little idea of what you're doing. You also have to learn their food and drink order codes while taking their orders. As a result, your first few weeks working will be a total nightmare and it's not a place for slow-learners or slow-paced people.

One food item and two different drinks are provided as a staff meal for every shift, which is barely enough to work 7 hours.

Some outlets have terrible partners that behave poorly in front of customers, which includes throwing a tantrum and threatening them. Few managers sadly condone their unacceptable attitude. 

Slow career advancement for full-timers, including long-term ones, since you're competing with many others for higher positions.

Most underpay job in the market, unless burning passion for the company or coffee itself, not recommended if looking for a decent paycheck. 

Little to no benefits to part-time workers even though sometimes you may clock almost similar hours to a full time Barista. 

No career progression despite advertisement, although this is subjected to employee competency and attitude. On the management side, skills to nurture and identify potential employee are lacking.

review_title: The Best, in Comparison to Other Companies I Worked For
pros:
1) Operations - Operations at store level is a nuthouse in itself, however primary & secondary duties have always been clearly outlined, hence partners can truly focus on building relationships and maintaining smooth operations. 
2) Benefits - All store partners receive free Restricted Stock Units(RSU) in the place of AWS (not sure about Support Centre partners). Quarterly performance bonuses are given if the store performs. Medical, maternity leave, etc. & their related benefits are applicable even for part-timers. Since I left, SBUX implemented flexi work positions, even for store level positions. Partners enjoy discounted prices on food, beverages & merchandise. Partners get to take home a bag of coffee or Tazo tea monthly. Oh! and you will never go hungry or thirsty at work. Did I miss anything out?
3) Workplace -  Work environment can be pretty vibrant, especially in a mid- or high volume store. From my personal experience, SBUX culture & values are strong - all partners in any store I've worked at, regardless of position, have placed efforts to truly make it the second home. Have made many longtime friends there.
4) Career Progression - L & D department exists for a reason: all new hires will undergo training to equip them with all the relevant skills. And SBUX is more than happy to promote internally. Make your intentions known, do consistently well daily & for annual performance review, and you're on your way. And if you don't have the relevant qualifications, they'll send you on your way to obtaining it. Kindly note T & C applies.
5) Senior Management & Support Centre - Who does what is clearly defined, so I had no trouble seeking assistance when needed.
cons:
1) Operations - It's a nuthouse - said it before. SBUX has loads of SOPs, operations-wise. Be prepared to follow through with them and and record the books constantly. The crowd can and will be overwhelming at times, especially during peak hours. SBUX work culture is very DIY, so do expect bussing, dishwashing, store cleaning, restroom cleaning (for some stores) etc. as part of the jobscope. Yup! You clean your own store. This extends to equipment maintenance as well.
2) Benefits - Value of RSU is pegged to the current SBUX stock price, which fluctuates, not good when stocks are down. Partners will need to follow the stock market and exercise much patience if they want to make the most out of their RSUs. #exercisepatience
3) Workplace - You do get the nasty customers. I especially dislike the freeloader types - they can scream at your face and abuse the "Just Say Yes" policy. I faced too many for too long that i became unfazed by such treatment and learnt to work around such situations. #exercisepatience.

review_title: Great company if you can handle it
pros:
The benefits are out of sight. I was offered Starbucks stock after my first year, as well as 401k through Fidelity, and a superb Blue Cross Blue Shield health insurance plan. You can cover your whole family with that plan, and it can include domestic partners. I got a pound of free coffee every week and free coffee all day (although I think that was specific to my store, which bent the rules). There's also an Employee Assistance Hotline which you can call if you're having issues in your personal life. And HR is really responsive--they won't see you as a troublemaker if you're legitimately having an issue. They will handle it.

Also, sexual orientation and gender identity are included in their anti-discrimination policy. None of the gay or lesbian people on my staff got crap for it, even though about half the staff was quietly conservative Christian and Republican.

If you're a people person, you develop relationships with the regulars and it's fun to make their day. I felt it was pretty rewarding to make drinks. I loved the artistic side of it. And again, the free coffee...just awesome. 

They're also usually pretty flexible about scheduling, so it's ideal for if you're working two jobs or are a student. I worked with people in their 50's who had their own careers, but worked part-time at Starbucks for the health insurance. 

The vacation time system is also pretty sweet. I worked with a guy who was there for 10 years and took like a month vacation to his home country.  

The staffs can be really tight...or they can be really vicious. But a spirit of teamwork is definitely encouraged. And exemplary work is recognized.

In an 8-hour shift you get three breaks: one 30-minute clock-out lunch, and two 10-minute on the clock breaks.

You'll also occasionally get those amazing customers and you live for seeing them. We had four customers who every year each put 100 bucks in our tip jar around Christmas. Sometimes those people can make your day with the things they say and do.
cons:
If you work at a store worth their salt they will work you to the bone. Especially in a large or high-volume store there is so much to do, so much to clean. A morning shift person will have the absolutely insanity of a morning rush, but an evening person should be expected to handle evening rushes with a limited staff as WELL as get the place spotless in what I believe is not a reasonable time. We could get the place clean by 10:45, all right--if we broke the health and corporate rules about when to tear things down. And of course if that was ever found out we were in deep. And if we went over 10:45 we were also in trouble. Management sometimes has some very unrealistic ideas about what the job actually entails and what rules and boundaries should go with that.

The pay in my state starts near minimum wage. The ceiling for a barista is $10/hr, which you hit when you've been there about five years. But tips help, and some high-volume affluent stores will have tips up to $4/hr.

There's also a tendency to have fanatical management. Other "kindly" corporations like Whole Foods have this too--the managers drink the Kool-Aid and worship the company. I once spoke with my manager because my schedule was being changed with less than 24 hours notice, and that was against state law. She got this crazed look in her eye and spat "Starbucks law goes above state law!" But that's only a tendency. There are some pretty cool managers out there. Mine was insane.

The customers are spoiled rotten so they also get kind of unreasonable about their Starbucks. They will stand there and demand that you make a drink five times because there's still foam on that latte and they said NO foam, not LIGHT foam. This is a business model of Starbucks': everyone is special, and we will bend the rules for everybody. And I've had people scream at me and call me a (b) and promise me that they would make me lose my job. I've also had stuff thrown at me. But, that's also just customer service.

These last few years Starbucks has been obsessed with selling, too. There's a lot of pressure on the staff to make sure people go home with $15 bags of coffee and sub-par espresso machines. It's hard to maintain the relationships they want us to maintain while trying to sell stuff.

Overall, if you can put up with the customers and the physical demand, and if benefits are more important than income, do it. It's rewarding in its own way. Wear insoles.

review_title: A Comprehensive Review of Working as a Store Manager at Starbucks
job_title: Store Manager in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Competitive Salary: Starbucks offers a competitive salary and benefits package to its store managers. This can be a significant incentive for many people to consider this job. Career Advancement: Starbucks has a culture of promoting from within. As a store manager, you will have the opportunity to grow your career within the company, and you may eventually become a district manager, regional manager, or even higher. Free Coffee and Benefits: As a Starbucks employee, you will receive a free bag of coffee or box of tea every week. You will also be eligible for benefits such as health insurance, 401(k) plan, and paid time off. Community Engagement: Starbucks has a strong commitment to community engagement and social responsibility. As a store manager, you will have the opportunity to participate in local events, charitable initiatives, and sustainability programs.
cons: Long Hours: As a store manager, you will be responsible for opening and closing the store, which means working early mornings and late nights. This can be challenging for people with families or other commitments. High Stress: The job of a store manager can be stressful, particularly during busy periods. You will need to be able to handle high-pressure situations and manage a team effectively. Customer Service: Dealing with customers can be challenging, particularly when they are unhappy or difficult to deal with. As a store manager, you will need to have excellent customer service skills to keep customers happy and coming back. Operational Demands: As a store manager, you will be responsible for ensuring the store is running smoothly and efficiently. This means dealing with operational demands such as inventory management, ordering supplies, and overseeing staff schedules.

pros: I loved my job for many years. I rolled with a lot of changes, grew with the company, got excited about growth, made a ton of friends and connections and some amazing networking opportunities. My customers were awesome. My coworkers were awesome. The benefits were outstanding. The schedule was flexible and we had a lot of fun as a team....
cons: ...and then it all fell apart. And FAST. The last two years have seen a shift so remarkably huge it's almost like stepping into the twilight zone. Every day I kept thinking, "this can't be the same company I have always loved." Because it isn't. It's basically McDonald's. You have managers barking at you to get the DT times down to under 50 seconds, and yet they turn around yell at you for customer connections scores, which are low because how can you connect in 45 seconds? Also they make you keep the window open in sub-zero temperatures because it's an opportunity to "connect." Man, if I were a customer I'd be like "dont talk to me it's freezing" lol.

review_title: Great Perks and Benefits, Rest of it is a joke
pros: Great benefits, the perks are great. tuition reimbursement and extended health benefits. free drinks and coffee weekly was great. its cool being able to learn about coffee and explore making different drinks
cons: Management is a joke. they are too worried about being liked by their staff(friends) to do their jobs. they scapegoat people to take care of problems and lack transparency when it comes to hours. I was a supervisor and I was lucky to get 30 hours a week but they were hiring new staff telling them they would receive 40 hours (only to later get 8 hours a week) the way that investigations are done is insane, managers type down what the partner says and relays that to the DM or RM.........how do you know your managers are being accurate in what they're typing. I worked for Starbucks in 2013 and compared to now the quality of leadership has decreases substantially.

pros: Coworkers and store management tend to be great, higher pay than other similar jobs, benefits available if you work at least 20 hours a week, tips have gone up since digital tipping has been implemented, food and drinks are free while working, very lgbtq+ friendly environment, flexible scheduling.
cons: Any management that is a district manager or higher is grossly out of touch with actual working environment, store management is highly variable by store, the company switches out store managers between location nearly every 2 years, increased outside management hires, physically demanding, customers have been getting ruder and ruder, emotionally exhausting, many managers take their stress out on their shift supervisors, you're expected to drop everything on your days off to cover shifts, people get fired for being late but not for racism, union busting, more focused on speed than quality

review_title: Changed culture and big risk of petty gossip
pros: — You get PTO after 12-months. — Part-time benefits (currently 18 hours but might change back to 20) — IF you’re lucky, you get a boss who cares and understands the job which will eliminate toxic culture. But thats rare. — I love connecting with my customers. If you are able to enjoy that and cut out the drama-noise, this could be okay.
cons: I worked at Starbucks before the pandemic and came back after. The culture has changed SO much. My particular store was full of back-of-the-room gossip with smiles in front of faces. Shifts would rather complain and have a scapegoat in the store than to actually do their jobs and coach. Management is a joke. Starbucks tends to hire outside of the company for managers who either don’t care to learn our drinks or are too overwhelmed with expectations to be able to learn. Coaching is gone. Make it right is gone. Team work is gone. Etc. There’s a reason so many are unionizing now. Promotion is hard. And it stings extra when you see managers getting hired who don’t know the different between a latte and cappuccino. I have a hearing loss and learning disability. My boss mentioned there being accommodations, but no actions were taken. It took me a long time to get the team to have some level of compassion for it, even when I explained the best way to communicate with me. It’s a popularity contest there. Even when multiple customers mentioned enjoying me and praising my service, they just made the team more petty.

pros: Starbucks is widely recognized for its outstanding employee benefits and company culture. From healthcare and tuition assistance to free coffee and employee discounts, Starbucks goes above and beyond to ensure its employees feel valued and supported. The company also places a strong emphasis on diversity, inclusion, and sustainability, which creates a positive and welcoming work environment for all. Overall, Starbucks is a great example of a company that prioritizes the well-being and happiness of its employees, and it shows in the quality of service and products they provide.
cons: The company's environmental impact, with concerns about the amount of waste generated by their single-use cups and the carbon footprint of their operations. Finally, there have also been some reports of labor issues, including low wages and poor working conditions for some Starbucks employees. While the company does offer many benefits and perks for its workers, these concerns have led some people to question the overall ethical and social responsibility of the company

pros: -You get to work with some of the friendliest partners -I’ve always felt supported in my role -Friendly customers who comes in and appreciates you for making them coffee/their favourite beverage -lots of training and really good training programs too! -30% staff discount -training systems works well, policies and procedures are updated. -gift card bonuses if you are awarded partner of the quarter
cons: -While I always felt supported, I noticed others didn’t. Store Managers don’t always work at the same capabilities and don’t always support the team on the bar/front of house service as they should. -Labour can sometimes feel tight, even though it’s above 20%, there’s always so much to do and not everyone can achieve their store goals with tight labour targets. -I wish there were more benefits for the partners like wholebeans & tea mark outs, beanstocks, more discounted staff parking rates nearby. -Career progression feels like a very long journey. -Supervisors and Assistant Managers don’t get paid that much more than their previous roles as baristas/Supervisors. They have more responsibilities but their pay isn’t noticebly higher, maybe like $1 or $2.

pros: I loved getting to know each of my co-workers! It’s a diverse background, but unfortunately a revolving door. Benefits for an entry level job.
cons: The job is stressful and often times feels understaffed. Consequently, making partners feel undervalued. While other managers sit in the back on their company sponsored, MacBook and pretend to be productive. You can spot the noticeable difference with managers who have a passion for what they do and managers who are just working for a pay check. Did I forget to mention, that store managers get quarterly bonuses based on productivity. For example, if their store preformed better than expected with the least amount of barista hours paid out. Starbucks apparently thinks it’s okay to pay out the managers for the work baristas carried out. Rather than giving bonuses to those baristas who worked those high stress hours. While the store managers had their lovely weekends off.

review_title: Positive environment with alot of false promises
pros: Very good job to make friends. Great if you love to meet and talk to people. Positive and accepting working environment. Fast paced and active work makes it hard to get bored.
cons: Outrageous hour cuts, impossible to make a living as a barista. You never know when you will practically not have your job for a reason out of your control. Management sees you as very disposable. Customer connections are forced and can feel awkward and unnatural. Very difficult to move up. Nepotism and favoritism among managers. Management does not care how long you have been there or the amount of work you put in for them. There are no incentives to go above and beyond. Still no promotion after a year and a half in favor of the managers friends and family members. The positive and accepting environment attracts some bad people since no one will check them on their behavior. I had a coworker constantly say horrible things about coworkers and customers for over a year before the DM finally fired him. Have to pester management to get training bonuses. Some rude and narcissistic customers. You will constantly be out of stock of things and have to deal with telling people.

review_title: overall a great place to work
pros: Each store is run a little differently and the whole tone is set by the management, baristas and regulars/customers. If everyone works together, it can be a fun work environment. If there's any toxic energy, you'll immediately feel the negative work environment. I worked in a store that had the highest sales. Our store had a tight knit staff and everyone got along with each other for the most part. My store manager was always very supportive and helpful. Our store was in a neighborhood, so the regulars were great and never a huge issue.
cons: Corporate will expect a lot from the store manager that can put stress onto the shift managers and trickle down to the baristas. Sometimes, they'll have unrealistic standards. If there's small changes (i.e. prices go up), the baristas will receive the backlash and blame from the customers. Corporate will only allow baristas to work a maximum of 25hrs/week. This job is only part time, so it's good for people who are in school or want a second job. It's very hard to move up in the company. Baristas can be promoted to shift, but only if you're well liked or a favorite and have worked there for at least 1 year. Corporate requires management to work full time (maximum of 40hrs/week) Starbucks is open 365 days a year, so expect to be required to work at least on holiday.

pros: There are no pros to this job because Starbucks has people who lack major communication.
cons: More Cons for the beginning of job. They only give you maybe 32 hrs of training which is really nothing on showing how the language works in conjunction with performing or making a drink. They knock your hours down to 8 hrs week as a recently hired person. It is horrible because when interviewed under the impression that it would be somewhere close to 30 hrs. However, that is not the case. They make you clean floors instead of learning about coffee. They gave a "talk off" of no one was certified to train on the floor. Many cleaning violations/ health code problems. No resources for proper cleaning; sponges thrown on the ground to clean dishes. Very un-hygenic and can make some one sick. So, instead of training someone how to do coffee, Starbuck, has health code problems,. I know that Starbuck is also in Labor disputes with many employees and now I can seee why. Many people need jobs and with the insane cost of inflation ; I wonder if this is deliberate. Starbucks might not last long with this business model very much longer, so I would not invest in Starbucks as a business model. It is only good for maybe learning how they make coffee, but their standards of cleaning are horrible. Telling someone they are hired as a coffee barista is not the same as a cleaning person. However, this is how they treat people now. Third world country stuff.

review_title: Company Was Great, But Can't Currently Recommend
pros: Great benefits & hourly pay compared to other food service jobs, free pound of coffee beans each week, free drink and meal on shift, free Spotify premium, discount on merch if you collect it. I worked during COVID and at the time in my personal opinion, I felt greatly supported by Starbucks who allowed me to choose whether to work or stay home based on my personal needs and concerns. Starbucks seemed in my opinion to take COVID more seriously than other retail jobs in my area.
cons: Company is fiercely opposed to unions and with the ongoing nationwide union drive, Starbucks' pushback against the union has dramatically increased the stress of the working environment. Stores that have voted to unionize have not been able to secure a contract so there is still no resolution to this concern. Meanwhile, there are serious issues with Starbucks' integration of alternate ordering options: whereas ordering through the drive-thru or in café is naturally prevented from occurring too quickly to manage, ordering through mobile or DoorDash currently has no restrictions or hold times for when the store is too busy to take additional orders. Mobile and DoorDash orders can be turned off with upper management approve but most managers do not want to give approval even when understaffed, so it would make much more sense to limit mobile orders so that customers must check in once they arrive before it submits their order to the barista's prep cue and charges their card.

pros: Lots of benefits amazing coworkers that will bend over backwards for you. If you want hours there are definitely hours there if you're willing to cover shifts and come over on your days off. It is a very inclusive company and you won't feel left out.
cons: There are some labor intensive drinks that are annoying to make and there are some customer demands that are ridiculous.

pros: The job itself is great. Its so much fun making drinks and working a shift.
cons: The pay is unreasonable for everything that is required and expected of you. You are expected to go above and beyond, but your paycheck will not go above and beyond with you. I can stress enough how poor the management is. If you are being berated by customers or fellow staff, your managers will always take the customers/manager's side. Speaking of customers, most of them are so entitled and stuck up, it will leave you shocked. Training is only 3 days long and then you are thrown into the fire. Store managers do show favoritism. You will find that regardless of how strong a work ethic you have, they will not promote you if they do not favor you. I worked with managers that didn't have a clue just because they were friends with the store manager outside of work.

review_title: Difficult job, but worth the pay.
pros: The pay is great, part time I'm making 15.91 an hour plus tips, which is much higher than any other job I could get. Even as a part time employee I'm given some benefits: free counseling, free Spotify, a pretty killer discount on Starbucks products.
cons: This is hard work. Physically exhausting, during rush I'm expected to make a drink a minute, and other positions have me running all over. Sone of these customers are unbearable, starbucks has good supports built in for us to help us manage them, but I've never had such rude customers in my life.

job_title: Shift Supervisor in San Jose, CA
pros: Free bachelor's degree, tips, if you become a trainer you get a bonus for every person you train. If you workout with 3 or more baristas theu can give you money towards it. Free stocks every year, 7 free food items a week, free coffee while you work, 1lb of beans a week, there's an entire website that has deals with starbucks to give employees discounts, they have groups to join if your passionate about something, etc.
cons: Opening is early, your job entirely depends on people in your store and your store manager they can make your job awesome or they can make your life hell.

pros: Pay, benefits, vacation, bonuses (just make sure you actually know every in and out of how these policies work or they will dwindle away QUICKLY
cons: Over 80% of the entire company has only been there 6 months or less so the training and support for a newcomer is lacking to say the least. They will take your bonus for a large variety of reasons that you didn't even know existed! Be prepared to have NO life, don't make plans, don't get sick and the only way you will actually get a day off is to have a peer cover for you on your day off! Oh and if you have a complaint and "challenge the status quo" like they say they want in their partners be prepared for them to tell you your wrong and that your not embracing the Starbucks way. HR is a joke!

review_title: Great company, but poor team dynamics
pros: The company values are great and are reflected in the way they treat their employees and customers. The training provided is thorough and helps you develop skills that are transferable to other areas of your life. The pay and benefits are competitive compared to other similar companies in the industry.
cons: The seniority culture is very prevalent, which can be frustrating if you are trying to advance your career based on your skills and abilities. There is a lot of bullying that goes on within the teams, which can make work very uncomfortable and stressful.

pros: Great way to learn how the corporation operates from within, their learning systems and what they do to supplement a livable wage.
cons: Manager refused to finish training me due to my aspirations as a bartender. Manager reduced my hours just one week before I was eligible to apply for benefits and never clarified how to apply for any rewards. Manager forced me to clean floor two days in a row, the heavy physical labor caused me to miscarry. I was never given my last paycheck. Fellow employee had a tree on property fall on her car and no manager was willing to help her. Customers were abusive and often times combative due to lack of regulations directed at the customer.

review_title: Lack of support in interpersonal conflicts, but good job
job_title: Shift Supervisor in Greenfield Park, QC
pros: Had a good relation with clients and loved the job Being a barista, I loved making drinks at the espresso machine. The team often worked well together during rushes Amazing relation with regulars Teaches people how to develop and enrich customer connection skills
cons: Management was not always the most supportive, Which could cause conflicts when things became ambiguous and the team didn’t know what direction to take. Things became more stable before I left as the manager became more experienced and recognized she had to take action. However, we became more organized at a cost. Despite being paid 16 dollars an hour, I was expected to keep a journal of my ‘pods’ development. As well as write a summary of my shift not only in a book at work, which is expected for bookkeeping, but in a group chat on Facebook marketplace. Ultimately I was satisfied with the job, but I left for better opportunities because the amount asked of me compared to the pay I received did not feel justified.

job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Winnipeg, MB
pros: Decent compensation outside of hourly pay including benefits for part-time work and stock benefits.
cons: Starbucks created a customer culture that effectively rewards treating the staff poorly. Stores were always run with as few partners as possible so if there is a sick call and someone can't make it in that day the entire shift is then left struggling. Management will often work behind the counter during busy periods to judge the work of lower-level partners and make critiques on the fly. Managers are not promoted on merit but on their obsession to Starbucks corporate culture.

pros: Coffee, People, health insurance, and community. I was the person that I always wanted to be. Management at my store worked with me so that I had time to take on IT contracts around the state. Being at the store was a positive experience.
cons: After I left in 2019 the Management moved toward making it more like Mcdonalds'. 2020, during the Pandemic, the culture fell apart and many partners were left to fend for themselves in dealing with increasingly hostile customers.

job_title: Certified Shift Manager in Bradford, England
pros: Nothing, very bad and unprofessional
cons: Everything. Nothing you do is good enough, everyone works hard for nothing, it’s cult like praising other stores while not focusing on own store problems, over worked, many managers do 5:45am until 11pm (later if busy) because they hire under 18s and they cannot stay past a certain time, or sickness. Low staff in general. NOT SAFE. at least once a week I would have to call the police as someone was violent etc, one time a man was walking around with a knife, the store has been ‘fire bombed’ twice, people have been run over outside of the store, staff have been followed home by customers, not safe and nothing done about it, asked higher management to ban these types of people and they won’t allow it, risking own staff safety. All about diversity however won’t allow tattoos, piercings, coloured or patterned clothing basically anything that makes someone unique, there’s a look book with plain clothing such as browns, beiges, black and that’s all you can wear so not really diversity? Also no work life balance, cannot get two days off in a row, tend to put same people on opens/closes, send same people home early, if quiet because basic staff are on 0 hour contracts they get sent home and not allowed to refuse, can be at work for as little as an hour and half before sent home again.

pros: amazing staff free drinks during your shift 7 free food mark outs per week 1 free coffee bag per week room for promotions if desired medical insurance benefits fidelity 401k retirement plan
cons: the customers overall treat you like garbage. i work at west tennessee by fsu campus and we’re slammed with college students who think we can make their drink right when they place it or tallahassee natives who get mad at us because the college student’s drinks take awhile since they ordered so many and we make drinks in the order they print

review_title: one of the best companies to start with
pros: I am considering if coming out to say this things, with fear that it may become too hard for others to get hired by Starbucks. When I say, they are one of the best companies out there, i mean it. They have sick time, PTO, vacation time, tips, stocks, flexible schedule, and don’t even get me started with how well they treated they employees during covid lock down. i grew with the company and i will always carry their spirit within me, wherever i go.
cons: Cleaning duties, rude customers, fast paced environment, few micromanaging situations (beware i worked in different stores).

pros: Starbucks benefits. Awesome coworkers. Ability to try and make whatever drink you want. Fun at the espresso bar.
cons: POOR Corporate management. They do not care about employees. They rather hire out hires than promote within. Especially store managers that are supposed to somehow "run the store." But have no idea what they are doing. Always understaffed and expected to pull greatness out of literally nothing. Under appreciated. Rude customers as if that was the worst thing though. In retail you always have those people. Work life balance doesn't exist. Used to be all about the partner experience and now is nothing but the money gain. Sad, over worked, under appreciated partners that just want to make coffee. 😪

pros: The free drinks/food item was really very nice, as was the free spotify, they do have a lot of nice employee perks but it really feels like that would be only reason to keep working here.
cons: It feels like an assembly line for coffee. It may be efficient sort of but it is not remotely enjoyable. It feels like the employees drank the koolaid and only speak of this place as perfect and their whole life (in a good way). But they were horrible to work with. Their universe is starbucks and I don't really feel that way about most service industry jobs. It's great to really love your company. But not by losing your humanity. Also horrible costumers.

review_title: Decent enough. Typical food service annoyances.
pros: I worked here all through college. It was good enough for what it was. Better than waitressing. Pay was okay and my store used to have raises twice a year but got rid of it during covid. Made good friends too
cons: Got rid of biannual raises at my store. My store also started policing what drinks we could make for ourselves by the time I left. It was dumb. Lots of turnover, I had to train a lot of people but I wasn’t paid more for this. People who kissed up to management usually got better positions. It is what it is. I worked there 3.5 years and had a different night manager every year. I knew more than them. BTW I was not at a corporate store so we didn’t have the same benefits and was subjected to more rules.

review_title: Chaotic and fast paced, but balanced
pros: My manager happens to be exceptional, though I know not all managers in our district are. He always approves time off, works on the floor with us, and has a great awareness of everything which helps make our time working significantly better. We have flexible scheduling and good benefits, we get free coffee and food when working, my coworkers are all very friendly, and we know what our schedule will be at least 3 weeks out, which for me is huge.
cons: The job can just be very fast-paced and high stress at times. Multiple coworkers and I agreed that there are sometimes days where, the second you get in your car you just start screaming. Your day can sometimes vary a lot by who your shift lead is, and a bad shift can absolutely ruin your day, as can a bad customer interaction. But these days are certainly outweighed by the neutral and good days. Can be difficult to get the hours you need. Raises are few and far between.

pros: They have incredible benefits that add to an employee's standard of living. Also, you meet great people in the workplace and life-long friendships can be formed. There's flexibility in scheduling so you can have a work/life balance. There are also opportunities for career advancement,
cons: They need to improve their training process for new employees. Only managers receive proper training while every other position's training tends to be subpar. This differs from store to store but training should be consistent across all stores.

pros: Very diverse and progressive coworkers and customers to work with. Amazing Benefits
cons: Hours are wildly inconsistent. Tied to amount of customers and not on a livable wage.

review_title: Minimal support and protection for employees
pros: Hands-on experience in an environment that encourages you to learn efficiently and quickly. Some customers can make your week.
cons: Absolutely no protection for employees. There were too many times I was required to go in to open the store alone during dangerous snow storms or power outages. Your life is more important than a cup of coffee but management simply does not see it that way. If you're sick you better hope someone on the team feels bad enough to help you out otherwise you'll be harassed to find coverage even if you're in the hospital. Management claims they care but they'll simply say that to save face and then talk behind your back. If Karen is still the manager there - apply to another location.

pros: Depending on management, this job can be a really great job for you in college. The free drinks are nice, and its interesting to experiment with different flavor profiles. If you are creative with what you drink, you will probably like it here.
cons: The leadership on a corporate level is making increasingly bad decisions as the days go by, and these do become apparent on all levels of working here. Be prepared to follow stupid rules that harm the customer experience they always go on and on about.

review_title: A lot to learn but worth the work
pros: Now that the minimum pay has risen to 15$ and hour, this job is definitely worth the work. You do have your fair share of rough customers, but that's expected. Learning about coffee and the culture was great, and I've taken what I've learned on with me in my current customer service roles.
cons: Unruly customers- because you can customize your drink down to the exact temperature, etc. You will run into some tough people

review_title: Great people to work with, okay pay but otherwise not a great job
pros: The people who work there are really great people The pay is okay manager is accommodating to availability requests of employees
cons: starbucks as a company cares more about targets than its customer service commitment and the coffee culture it used to be known for targets set can be so un realistic staffing issues are rife throughout the company, they do not provide managers with enough labour coverage to be able to meet their unrealistic targets they set causing baristas to be stressed and unhappy on shift

pros: I really value my coworkers, most of seem to mesh together really well. There's great benefits associated with the company such as Spotify, Stock investments etc. The pay is starting to get better, I understand that this is not a difficult job, and doesn't require higher education than basic secondary education.
cons: I work in a location with terrible clientele. They are very rude to all staff regardless of what we do to remedy the situation. Tired of Starbucks constantly taking the customer's side and not backing their employees. It has caused many great employees to leave after years of service. This has only increased in frequency since I have began working here. Hours have been recently sliced almost in half for some people due to it being the slower season after the holidays, this typically happens every fiscal year. The app can be glitchy and the baristas have to bear the brunt of abuse from customers who are obsessed with "earning stars".

pros: Free college Meet some really cool people Making drinks is fun Really learn how to get out of your comfort zone
cons: Unpredictable hours, management can be very clicky, have had some really bad supervisors that never get in trouble honesty they kinda get praised even though they are mean to baristas or other supervisors. So many call outs and you are always expected to stay to cover No seniority is given honestly new people are treated better than ones who have been around a long time

pros: Great benefits, great people!(as long as you get great managers)
cons: If someone is out to get you, they'll go right to PRSC with a complaint that will get you fired, instead of having a 1 on 1 with a leader in the store. They don't take anything lightly, and this is why people are unionizing, because there are no protections for one-offs.

review_title: Only stay for the benefits and free tuition, have another job for the bills
pros: Only stay to get your free tuition, good health care, 401k, investments, and employee discounts. They don't give you a living wage. Make sure you have another job lined up for finances or use this job to support your family with benefits. The company can't take a stand when it comes to their policies regarding the first place in the cafe and covid precautions.
cons: You deal with Karen's Your not paid a living wage for all the work you do They never fix their equipment They never take a stand on their policies because it's about appeasing thr clientele. You have to leave the company and rejoin in order to get promoted. Outsiders have more of a chance of promotions than people who have been with the company longer. They refuse to hire security for stores in high level crime areas and high areas of substance abuse. If you unionize your store because corporate was useless in rectifying issues, your store will be shut down. The former CEO came back to the company because to ma y stores were unionized. They target shifts who openly talk about strikes and unionize. They will intimidate you and go against labour laws.

job_title: Store Manager in Overland Park, KS
pros: benefits. free college from ASU, chiropractic care, acupuncture care, medical, dental, vision, therapy, spotify membership, coffee discount, great people
cons: lost touch with mission. publicly held company so job performance boiled down to out the window readiness metric and customer connection scores. Arbitrary numbers that dictate labor budget allocation etc. A lot of virtue signaling and woke quackery.

pros: Benefits are not bad at all, free coffee, flexible schedule at least at my location, tips or not bad either
cons: Depending on who you work with, you will face some drama at one point. I had no sense of belonging, everyone hates working there, and no one cares. I worked with a bad batch, but still, I had experience in retail.. but as for coffee, I feel like I don't have the same excitement as before. Every time I try to learn no one wants to teach or they get mad at me for not learning fast enough.. if you want to work at a place where coffee is made poorly/fast, tiring, and sometimes mentally exhausting AND on top of that you have lots of nasty customers (but there are lots of nice ones too) this is the place for you. But this is just this area, not all Starbucks are like this, or at least that's how I see it.

pros: Flexible hours Discounts on products Free drinks
cons: Terrible management Constantly new and inexperienced workers Favouritism within staff Aggressively busy all the time Zero structure with hard workers taking the burden

pros: Benefits are competitive Pay is very gracious considering the current market minimum wage pay Light work duties
cons: Toxic customer is always right culture District management and store management respect towards store workers is a hit or miss (Cobb County, GA) Some shift leads behaving as if they are managers Not encouraged to speak up about what may be wrong fundamentally and told to 'suck up'

review_title: If you love free coffee and fast pace work environment
pros: - Free Spotify Premium - 401k match - Free Stock for every two years you work - Weekly food/coffee markouts - Good atmosphere amongst peers (store dependent) - Good employee discount

Managers not standing by corporates rules to make employees look less than competent in front of customers. Management putting in the schedules late then when employees ask to switch shifts and it’s ok with everyone else management will tell you the schedule isn’t finalized even if it’s already been posted and late being posted.

review_title: Covid changed Starbucks, not the same company I joined years ago.
pros: Good benefits and decent pay. You meet some really great people and learning the craft of coffee culture can be fun. The free tuition through ASU is a plus.
cons: Starbucks spoils their customers, and they're EXTREMELY entitled because of it. Covid brought out the company's true colors; they're just like any other company with corporate America values. The culture of Starbucks is gone; they only care for cranking out as many transactions as possible. Brought CEO Howard Schultz back to crack down on unions.

pros: Free drinks cool coworkers and free food
cons: Everything else is a con and they don’t look out for us ever and let’s the customers say, throw drinks, and cuss us out

pros: - Free bags of coffee. - Satisfaction of clocking out at the end of a shift. - Using hindsight in the present and laughing at how asinine it all is.
cons: - Pay is insufficient for the work expected. - Starbucks is an assembly line for coffee and the employees are the machines. I work at one of the busiest stores around and we're not even located in the main part of the city. Other Starbucks employees that have worked in more populated areas have left because of how chaotic it gets. - The entire Starbucks experience is abysmal. You have a system where people are ordering coffee from their phones, in-store, and for delivery, so the orders pile on. Delivery drivers are constantly coming in and out waving their phones asking for their order, while other customers are hanging over the bar staring at you and asking you questions while you're in the middle of preparing multiple drinks and having to remember orders that have six or seven modifications. - Incompetent and ignorant shift supervisors and managers.

pros: The tips are distributed evenly to everyone and is usually a decent cut. Food items and a drink are free for lunch breaks but are not healthy in the long run. They hire plenty of high schoolers and fresh out of high school students while they complete their degrees. They're always hiring. Good job for extra pocket money.
cons: If assigned to drive -thru, be prepared to make drinks, handle cash, and take orders with three or less staff members. Closing is mentally and physically demanding compared to opening shifts. Starting $9 an hour, I don't recommend this job for anyone who is solely relying on a living wage.

pros: Coworkers try to make family as there can be really no one without coworker families
cons: It put retail costs on welfare rights like coffee....so it's having to work for the executive that steals body matter for the offense to the poor....that was twenty years ago when the company was only 30 years old....now that it's 50 years old and still pressuring a dictative I have never seen a worse weight politic then it other then the McDonald's college concentration starvation plan...

cons: Sometimes not great or consistent work hours Customers can be a hassle to please or deal with

pros: Good team Good support Clear daily routines and structure
cons: Sometimes short-staffed Hard physical labour in comparison to other cafes

pros: The job is fun if you have good coworkers, which you usually will have, and there is always something that you can do.
cons: The job can be emotionally and physically exhausting, and it is easy to get burned out. Staffing is complex and shipments aren't coming in lately

review_title: Your partners care about you. Starbucks does not.
pros: If you get along well with your co worker the environment is great. The work culture here between employees is amazing and ive made a few friends through this. Good starting pay and free coffee during your shift days/discounts on days off
cons: Often the store feels like employees vs management Constantly understaffed and unsupported. Feels as if having to walk on egg shells Public Punching bag The customer's experience means more to them than your experience working here. 15 dollars an hour at base is not nearly enough to deal with the huge flow of customers with the amount of labor starbucks is willing to allow its store to use despite record yearly profits.

review_title: The store I worked at was great...
pros: Part-time benefits. LGBTQ+ friendly. Great partners.
cons: Not enough hours are given so that we are comfortable on the floor. We're always one person short of being able to do the job without being overwhelmed and stressed. Hours are also always being cut because corporate is trying to do more with less to bring in more money. The high turnover means you are often working with inexperienced partners so it's extra stress on the experienced partners to have to work and teach. Training only focuses on making drinks, not all the other stuff like tasks and opening or closing the store, which is easily 75% of the job. Partners are exposed to harassment and management is unable or unwilling to do anything. Speed of service has started to be prioritized over quality of service which puts more stress on partners and lowers the quality of service in the end. Labor is given based on the number of customers, not the amount of food/drink in an order so labor on the weekend is disproportionate to labor hours given to mornings during the week. On a Saturday, for example, a few cars will have $40 plus orders and make the same amount of money in a shorter amount of time compared to a weekday morning, but it's fewer cars so the amount of food/drinks made isn't taken into consideration when labor hours are being distributed. Basically working a Saturday mid shift is a nightmare.

review_title: Great place to start but not to stay!
pros: Free coffee, plenty of people to meet, great medical and stock options as well
cons: You cannot receive a raise no matter how hard you work. The only ways to increase your wage is to either waiting for the regular raise to come through or get a promotion which is very much so a popularity contest. Highly recommend keeping your nose to the ground, the turn over is so high that you will find your self being the last person standing in a year or two. Then, the new manager will see that and promote you.

pros: Starbucks is an amazing job for anyone! co workers are great!
cons: can feel like you are on call sometimes

pros: Being a barista can be very fun, making drinks for a few good customers and getting to chat while they enjoy something you made them is awesome. They finally implemented card tipping so that helps with some of the paychecks. Getting to mark out free coffee is cool.
cons: There is literally no customers like Starbucks customers, you think they can be bad but they are even worse to workers at Starbucks. They don't maintain anonymity when you file any claim against someone in the company which is a fast way to create an awful work environment. The turnover rate is stupidly high for any position in the company. They cut hours constantly, especially after any kind of raise. The coffee is poor quality, the beans aren't good, and always have a burnt taste especially due to the crap machines they use that constantly have issues. Managers can get away with pretty much anything while baristas are written up for just calling out sick or being less than 5 minutes late to clocking in. In two years I've gone through 4 managers already, none of them have been good so seems to be a thing for Starbucks.

review_title: There's a reason for the wave of unionization

job_title: Barista, Shift Supervisor in Arroyo Grande, CA

If your manager takes their job too seriously then they'll make you miserable in extension to themselves -Lots of callouts and having to work short staffed -You'll have to deal with a lot of very stupid and rude customers -Compensation sucks -inconsistent schedules and cut hours

pros: Free coffee Free Spotify The people I worked with were nice
cons: Customers being rude for reasons out of your control

pros: great environment and benefits, supportive company
cons: steep learning curve, most leave before they pick up on it

review_title: Great flexible job with amazing benefits!
pros: - Flexible hours (based on store operations/needs) - Many benefits (health, dental, partner discount, bean stocks, etc) - Overall great work environment!
cons: - Some stores may require you to be available for opening/closing shifts 2 or 3 times a week, and depending on everyone else's availability in your store, you may be scheduled opening/closing for those days you submitted (which may be a con for some people) - Not sure if this happens with other stores, but my store went through multiple manager changes during the 2.5 years I was working there, and I found that each manager had their own expectations of our performance and how certain products were organized in the store - I worked at a very busy store but despite our feedbacks and requests to have more coverage, management rarely ever provided room for additional coverage because the "data" showed that there were enough coverages based on our daily/hourly sales. so I feel like they are very data-driven with very little room for context and flexibility

job_title: Shift Supervisor in Lagrange Hlds, IL
pros: -great benefits -the job itself is easy - opportunities to move up (sometimes)
cons: -although the job is easy management makes it infinitely harder -hours got cut so baristas get between 12-18 hours per week and shift supervisors get 16-24 hours per week, which is not livable. -the hours are spread out so that you cannot get another job to supplement lost wages. I work five days a week with only 4 hour shifts which is a waste of time. -management will always choose the customers side. I’ve seen multiple baristas get fired when the customer was in the wrong. -under scheduled when we have people who want the hours but corporate won’t allow it. -district manager is also no help and condescending.

pros: Good benefits for a minimum of 20 hours. Partners are great, and discounts are awesome. Free spotify!
cons: Constant changes in work pace and work space. Most of the time there will be call-outs and short staffing. product quality can be not so great sometimes.

review_title: Not a good idea to work here
pros: Get employee’s benefit of 30%
cons: they pays really low One day, two people called managers came from the headquarters and brought cctv evidence that I stole the money, but in reality, i put the changes in the tip box. They didn't even apologize to me, and I was embarrassed, felt unfair, and upset because this was the first time I'd ever had this happen, and I kept crying. I was not able to work on that day but no one cared. I worked full time on that day.

pros: This is my first job--the bar for a retail position was on the floor, and my experience soares way over it. My partners are incredibly kind and supportive; Everybody is on board and willing to support trainees and new partners to get used to the environment and Starbucks standards. It's weird to look back and see the transition from trainee to unofficial trainer. We love new people, and we love veterans. The constant shifting of position has made this an interesting and engaging job. There's space to engage with people, knuckle down and make drinks, or take a break for a bit and retreat, restock, do dishes, etc. There's always more to learn, and there is certainly room for growth. Starbucks tries to market itself as a "career job" and honestly, its starting to show (granted, there is a roof and that's a store manager position). Still, this is something that I can only in good consciousness say if you are able to put up with constant people contact for over a decade. It's not exactly introvert-friendly. For most partners, this is a good place to pause and rake in dough while we work through college or new parenthood. Its nice to meet partners and see what their ambitions are, even if very few of them are related to Starbucks. We rarely encounter Karens. The only frequently frustrated customers are frustrated for good reason. (See the cons). The people that come to our store are so friendly. We love our regulars, and we LOVE pets. Hours are very flexible, pay is surprisingly high, there are annual increases, and the tips (usually $1 a hour) skyrocket during Christmas season. Specific holidays (i.e. Juneteenth, 4th of July, Halloween, Christmas, NYD) have the tips isolated specifically to partners that work that day, and partners are paid time-and-a-half.
cons: There is so much pressure and too little support when it comes to drive thru stores. The worse our drive times are, the less coverage we are allowed to schedule, which leads us to be understaffed and struggle to keep up with the demand. Its a harmful positive feedback loop that ends up breaking the backs of our shift supervisors, who get in trouble for bad drive times when they have only 4 people (including themselves) to run a store with. (And corporate is back-breakingly stubborn about turning off mobile orders if we need them off.) We are also constantly given our nearby store's new hires to train since they burn through partners, and it's putting a strain on us. We've had interim managers for seven months since the manager who opened the store was forced into medical leave and then eventually got into such a tangle with the regional manager when he tried to come back that he gave up. 0 support from regional manager. My store in particular is a unionized store. The last pro-union partner left five months ago. We haven't had a union rep in 9 months. Nobody wants this here, but nobody knows or is interested enough to undo it.

pros: My manager is great at what she does and fair when it comes to scheduling hours. The employees who have been working at my location for a long time are very reliable and work very efficiently, meeting all standards for drinks and customer service expectations.
cons: My location has experienced many issues with hiring baristas who only work for maybe a month before quitting. Some of these employees have no called-no shown and others have shown up hours late to their shifts. However, these employees often quit quickly.

pros: As fars a service industry standards goes, starbucks is a decent company to work for. From my personal experience where ive worked, they've treated me pretty well, but for the most part I am the type of person to put my head down and mind my own business for work, so take that into account. Good training, Good benefits (insurance is very good, free drinks, discounts, etc.) Decent work atmosphere (this is highly dependent on the store location/clientele and the management there) Sometimes decent managers/SLs
cons: Pay is not great in general, but for Customer Service jobs it is decent Very difficult to get enough hours for insurance or just to pay the bills in general It can be very stressful with not enough staff on the floor and lineups out the door with no one to assist it seems that the new trend is to hire outside the company for management positions, instead of training baristas to be SLs/Store Managers Sometimes or even often (depending on the manager) you can get Clopins (Close-Opens) and an erratic schedule that can be difficult to manage. Overall i would say this is a decent job to have when youre at school, or maybe an in between job (or just been layed off) to have while youre looking for something else.

Schedules would come in a week prior. Not the manager's fault as they were trying very hard. The company cares too much about profits and opening new stores. District managers feel like they can treat you like absolute crap and be nice to you in the next second.  They don't give a damn about their employees.

review_title: An honest review working at Starbucks
pros: -Free Food -Discounts. -Free college tuition -Medical, Vision and Dental Plans. -401k -Free Spotify -Free Headspace -Free therapy sessions via Lyra
cons: -It can get overwhelmingly busy every day. -Very rude customers -Breaks are nonexistent when you're working a shift under 6 hours, especially if you're trying to order food but there is a long line; your supervisors or store manager will not care if you are unable to eat your meal within your ten-minute break. -You will always start off as a part-time employee. Full-time hours are given to shift supervisors. You may ask for more hours, but you are not given a consistent full-time schedule but rather part-time. -Favoritism is apparent most of the time. -There's a chance that your supervisors and/or the store manager are condescending towards you. If so, they will patronize you in front of your co-workers. -Do not apply if you are not comfortable standing all day and are quick to anger.

review_title: Great Benefits BUT Partners have NO Voice in the Company
pros: Great benefits, meet many people daily, Free drinks and 1 free meal daily.
cons: This location is very cliquy, tried multiple times to address many issues within our store and our shift leader and managers would not listen. Terrible management and micro-management.

pros: The pay was decent whilst I worked there Good opportunities for promotion

pros: there are so many great benefits, 401k...if you're smart enough to know what it is and start putting money into asap....free food and drinks, college, healthcare....it has a lot

You need a leader and not many stores have good leaders and that's where it all begins, Find a store that has this and you will love it

pros: I really liked the people who worked there, I was able to make friends with them and they helped me a lot. It also has decent pay for a starter job. They have decent benefits.

review_title: It can honestly burn you out…

pros: Starbucks Coffee Company offers a competitive benefits package compared to other food service chains in the same market space. Their is a tangible impact and reward when product is delivered to customer. Fast-paced environment, supported by a staff encouraged to be positive and upbeat.
cons: Starbucks fails to veil their emphasis on profit and efficiency. Often they claim to be employee first, most company practices disregard safety and physical & mental well being. The emphasis on drive-thru metrics has negatively impacted the mission statement of the brand. Their products are detrimental to the environment and they are guilty of tremendous green-washing. Management positions are often outside hires and the lack of industry experience creates a strain on seasoned employees. Their labor metrics try to run skeleton crews, but the desired outcome of personal connection is strained from the disparity.

pros: You get free coffee every week period. A matching 401k. And Healthcare options. They will pay for your college only if you go to their chosen university and maintain a 2.0 the entire time.
cons: Even though healthcare cost less than in other places the actual care out of pocket cost can be expensive. The pay is low and doesn't pay the bills in particularly rent. Career advancement despite the advertisements is lower than they say you can work there for years and never get a promotion. The pay raise is at least 30 cents a year. The healthcare increases you can expect a 20 to $40 increase on most plans each year. Managers are incentivized to cut shifts short. They get a bonus for doing so. So if you're not your manager's favorite you can expect significantly reduced hours.

pros: I have been with Starbucks for 5 years now. I have just separated from the company to move onto a full-time career. The benefits of Starbucks - what kept me around for so long - was how great the benefits were! Whether that be free Spotify premium, stock benefits, school and health coverage, they have it all!
cons: Between all stores, management varies drastically. Some stores really create a culture of friendship and family, whereas other stores and store managers do not care as much about their employees or the culture that there is.

job_title: Store Manager in Fort Lauderdale, FL
pros: enjoying your team and building a trauma bond
cons: Senior leadership is super disappointing. Do not provide you with enough labor to service your customers. Senior leaders are so far removed from physical labor their brains cannot comprehend the amount of labor needed to successfully run a store where baristas aren’t exhausted and managers aren’t working 70 hours on the floor a week, let alone “run the business like it’s theirs.” Which includes making schedules, organizing/managing inventory, staffing - from having to find the talent, hire, train and coach. Being on call and available 24/7. Attend meetings, have 1x1 coachings with 20+ partners, never have a day off. They might as well pay for your phone because it is only used for work - say goodbye to any social life. OH and all of this to be expendable and considered free labor for less than $70k a year. It’s a good thing you’re always at work because you would not be able to afford to do anything else besides sleep and you’ll be really tired so it works out. Physically, mentally and emotionally exhausting. I started antidepressants because of Starbucks. TOXIC

pros: I am a full time student in university, have a full time unpaid internship, and work at Starbucks 20 hours a week. It is hard and exhausting, but my boss has worked with me more times than she should have to, and has ensured that I am okay. I was able to take on counseling with Starbuck's free 20 sessions. We have meetings with our district manager to determine what needs to change-and he actually listens.
cons: You cannot transfer to a different location unless you physcially moved. It is not based on preference. The work environment can get extremely stressful, especially during peak times. There is a lot of emphasis placed on Drive thru Times.

job_title: Shift Manager in Culver City, CA
pros: N/A - horrible in every way. Will start you at full-time and then take away your hours to give to kids still in high-school so that they don't have to give you benefits.
cons: Every aspect of the job. They do not care about your or your wellbeing. The amount of code violations I saw in two years was mind blowing. Literally everyday. In two years (2015-2017) I went from making $14 -$14.50 and I had to work through my clocked-out lunch because we were short-staffed and I was advised never to just not clock out due to the fine they would receive. I still can't believe I worked for free for these people who had absolutely no care for me. Was verbally accosted multiple times by homeless people and couldn't even get a call back from my manager or supervisor while filling out the work incidence reports they REQUIRED when police had been called.

pros: A typical day starts with opening the store with two other partners, one of whom is a shift supervisor. I have learned a lot about coffee, coffee tasting, the origins of coffee, and sustainability. The district manager is always on top of her game when it comes to providing feedback on your work. The partners and store culture make the moment right, creating a third place for customers. Interacting with other partners, learning how to do things correctly with the support of fellow colleagues in the same position, and connecting with customers daily is exciting.
cons: We are occasionally understaffed. Sometimes partners call out at the last minute and cannot get someone in to cover their shift.

pros: -Free College -Free Coffee -Free Therapy -Free classes to take on anything without having to enroll in college- financial literacy, management, coffee academy, etc.
cons: -1 hour of PTO for every 40 hours you work, takes forever to build up -There is no work-life balance. Store Managers (I've had 3) all expect you to be on-call and work off the clock to find coverage for unfilled shifts. -It is impossible to fire horrific partners who show up late every shift, have a poor attitude, take extra long breaks, and are rude to other partners and SSV's. -Under appreciated. The store can be looking perfectly clean, have excellent DT times, and you won't receive any praise from your SM. Just ideas on how to get 'better'. -Understaffed every day on purpose. The Store Manager and District Managers get a bonus if they understaff the stores. I have been told many ways on how to 'increase labor hours' to 'get more staffing' that has never worked. We are ALWAYS understaffed and not given enough time to complete everything. My store makes anywhere from 8-10k a day, and we only have enough 'labor hours' to get 5 people for peak? -No holiday pay for the busiest, most stressful day of the year (Red Cup Day). -Expected to work most holidays -No shift premium pay for opening the store at 4:30am most days.

pros: Employee Benefits: Starbucks provides its employees with a variety of benefits, including health care, tuition reimbursement, and a 401(k) retirement plan. Even part-time employees can be eligible for some of these benefits. Flexible Scheduling: Starbucks offers flexible scheduling to its employees, which can be helpful for those who have other commitments or obligations. Employees can often work around their personal schedules, and there may be opportunities for part-time or full-time positions. Training and Development: Starbucks invests in the training and development of its employees, which can help them build new skills and advance their careers. Employees receive training on customer service, product knowledge, and other important aspects of the job. Employee Discounts: As a Starbucks employee, you'll be eligible for discounts on food and beverages at Starbucks stores, as well as discounts on merchandise. Positive Work Environment: Many Starbucks employees enjoy working in a friendly and positive work environment, where they can interact with customers and coworkers. The company has a reputation for treating its employees well and creating a supportive work culture.
cons: entry-level positions is generally considered to be relatively low. Depending on the location and the employee's role, wages may be close to minimum wage. High Demand: Starbucks is a popular and busy coffee chain, and employees may be required to work in fast-paced and high-stress environments, particularly during peak hours. This can be challenging for some individuals, especially those who are new to the job. Physical Demands: Depending on the employee's role, working at Starbucks can be physically demanding. Employees may be required to stand for long periods, lift heavy items, or work with hot or cold equipment. Scheduling Inflexibility: While Starbucks offers flexible scheduling, some employees may find that their schedules are still inflexible or unpredictable, particularly if they are new to the job or working during busy periods. Customer Service Challenges: As a customer-facing role, working at Starbucks can come with customer service challenges. Employees may need to deal with difficult or irate customers, which can be stressful and emotionally taxing.
